group_1.textLeft: What in the world is Queen Isabeau thinking?
It was the support of the Duke of Burgundy that@let her get to her position in the first place
and now she's having an affair with Lord Louis,@of all people! His political rival...

group_1.textRight: Oh my God!
I just heard that some thugs attacked and killed@Lord Louis in the street...!

group_1.textLeft: Wha...?

group_1.textRight: He was on his way home from Queen Isabeau's@mansion.
The court is in an uproar over who assassinated@Louis.
The man responsible is Jean,@the current Duke of Burgundy,
who is also the son of the previous Duke, John.
The public opinion in Paris seems to favor Jean,@though.
You've been coming under scrutiny for betraying@the Duke of Burgundy
and getting close with his political rival, Louis.

group_1.textLeft: *chuckles*...
Do you think that matters to me?
...The Armagnac faction?

group_1.textRight: Yeah, that's the name for the newly-formed alliance
against the Burgundians.

group_1.textLeft: They're carryin' on the legacy of the king's brother@Louis...

group_1.textRight: That's the plan.
The leader of the Burgundians is, of course,@Jean of Burgundy.
...Along with Queen Isabeau.

group_1.textLeft: That lady got chummy with Lord Louis,@did whatever she wanted,
and then switched to the side of the guy who@assassinated him...
I swear she doesn't have a shred of respect@for ANYONE!

group_1.textRight: Thanks to them, France has been divided in two.
The Armagnac party is about to take Paris by force@soon.
We're gonna be busy.

group_1.textLeft: Civil war, eh?
It'll be a good time for us mercenaries@to earn some cash, but...

group_1.textRight: Is everything exactly where you want it to be?

group_1.textLeft: Not everything, but I am making progress.

group_1.textRight: France has split in two and is on the verge of@a civil war...

group_1.textLeft: I have several more tricks up my sleeve.
England has been watching us vigilantly,@waiting for an opportunity to intervene,
and my cute little daughters have been growing up@nicely.

group_1.textRight: Are you going to marry them off for diplomacy?

group_1.textLeft: Yes... Some of them have "potential", as well.

group_1.textRight: I see,@you're considering turning them into Magical Girls.
You take them out on excursions and everything.@You must love them a lot.

group_1.textLeft: Hmhm... I really do.
I'd like to keep them with me forever.

group_1.textRight: Wouldn't it be much quicker
to seize France if you used your magic?
You don't seem to be taking full advantage
of your gifts as a Magical Girl...

group_1.textLeft: It's more fun to savor the process of gaining power@and control.
I've been blessed with a body that will never age...@and a life that will never end.
Rushing to reach my goals would be nowhere near@as enjoyable.

group_1.textRight: "A life that will never end", huh...

group_1.textLeft: ...The Armagnac faction would then go on to install
Isabeau's son, Dauphin Charles VII,@as heir to the throne.
Jean of Burgundy, the man who had assassinated@the king's brother Louis,
was himself assassinated by the new Dauphin@Charles.

group_1.textRight: Yeah, what started as a father-son feud@has turned into a bloody conspiracy.
Isabeau was behind the English intervention
implying that Dauphin Charles was an illegitimate@child of no royal blood.
This caused trouble with the succession of the@throne...
Then, in 1420, the catastrophic Treaty of Troyes@was signed. It was decided that
the child born to Isabeau's daughter Catherine,@who had married the king of England,
would become the next king of France and England@alike.
All that was left was for the two kings to fall,
leaving Isabeau in charge of both countries.
And then...

group_1.narration: < Death of Henry V, King of England >
< Death of Charles VI, King of France >
< Birth of the dual kingdom of England and France >

group_1.textCenter: I did not come to France to be a decoration on some@king's arm.
